loans.name: Saleema

texts.en: “I run a hotel with my brother and three sons and need a loan to use as down-payment for a contract from the local city court who will give us catering business for a year. The business from the local will guarantee us enough income for a year as I am from Pakpattan located 200km from Lahore.”

loans.use: Use as downpayment for business contract

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: “I make wheat and barley flour at home, which my husband sells in the market. We have been doing this business in a village in Pakistan. It is easier for my husband to go out and do the transactions in the market place. Now we need a loan to purchase stock so that we can sell more in the market place. I have five children in school and I would like for them to continue their education.”

loans.use: Purchase stock

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
Rustam F. is 35 years old and has secondary education. He is married and has 3 children. He is a truck driver.

Rustam has been doing stockbreeding for 10 years. This activity is an additional income source which he gets from his cows' milk and meat. For the loan amount of $1000, Rustam is planning to buy 2 cows. This will increase both the number of his cattle and the quantity of their daily milk yield. His fresh milk will be sold to town inhabitants who don't have the opportunity to raise cows. Rustam is going to pay off the loan over a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Salma

texts.en: “I am a client of a MFI called Asasah in a small town in the province of Punjab and waiting for them to lend to me so that my sons can purchase equipment for our barber shop, a family business. My husband left for another woman a few years back and since then I have been living with my children. After having struggled a great deal, I am now too sick to work myself and require your assistance to help my children.” Salma B., Pakistan

loans.use: Purchase equipment

loans.name: Nusrat

texts.en: “I require a loan to help my husband set up his new barber unit and purchase equipment for it. The income will help continue to put food on the table and keep our children in primary school. We don’t have a barber shop yet, but my husband works on the roadside. Once day when his business expands, I hope he can operate from a proper barber shop.” Nusrat B., Pakistan

loans.use: Purchase equipment

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 23 years old, single, living with his mother and sister. He has a small shop to sell spare part for cars and vehicles. He got his shop from his father who died in a terrorist attack. He wants to purchase new goods. He wants to improve and enhance his life. He is looking forward to increasing his income.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note 1: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

Note 2: This loan is for a continuation of the loan term of this entrepreneur. This entrepreneur was accidentally posted with a loan term of 1 month earlier when the loan term should have been for 12 months. The remaining 11 months and the outstanding balance of $1,100 are captured in this loan.

loans.use: Purchase more goods

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: “I sew at home with my daughters to sell in the neighbourhood and also teach sewing skills to young girls. Since my business is too small and does not yield enough profit, I would like to borrow for my son who runs a rent-a-bike shop in a small town in the province of Punjab in Pakistan. I hope that business will ensure my son’s financial future.”

loans.use: Purchase a motor bike

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: “I sell animal skins and fodder as well as trading livestock. I am lucky enough to have a piece of land that I can use to keep my animals and would like $246 to purchase additional fodder to sell in the local market. My husband is only seasonally employed as we live in a small town where there isn’t much work to go around. I have five children, three of which are in government school. I make about $3 to $5 per day. Your loan will help me increase my family’s income.”

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: “My husband died a few years after we got married and I have no children. I live with my brother and his family in a rural area of Pakistan with the nearest metropolitan city about four hours away. I earn my livelihood by selling three to five tonnes wood daily in the local market and make a profit of about 33 cents per tonne. There are no financial sources of support available for me and require a loan so that I can purchase more wood to sell in the market.” Mariam B., Pakistan

loans.use: Purchase wood

loans.name: Faiza

texts.en: “I have ten children and live in a small town. I am too old to work myself but my youngest son wants to purchase a Rickshaw (local three wheeled vehicle). At present, he provides transportation service by renting someone else’s Rickshaw and makes only $2 to $3 per day. If purchases his own Rickshaw with a loan he will be able to make $5 to $7 per day. He has finished primary school and then dropped out because he did not like studying much.”

loans.use: Purchase a Rickshaw

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en: “I have been sewing clothes at home for the past 22 years with my daughters. I live in a small town located about 200km from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. All my children work but my family requires a loan for our furniture and rent-a-bike business. We will then be able to purchase more wood and a second hand motor bike for renting to customers in our town.” Hamida B., Pakistan

loans.use: Purchase materials for rent-a-bike and furniture shops

loans.name: Zahara

texts.en: Zahara lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a carpet weaver. She recently started this business and she needs money to complete the purchase of all her materials. She wants to take a group loan to buy new looms. She wishes to work hard and export carpets to different places in Afghanistan to attract more clients and make a good income for her family.

loans.use: To buy new looms

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en: Maryam lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is uneducated and a widow. Her husband died during the war in Kabul. She is still supporting her family. She is a seamstress. She wants to expand her business so she wants to take a group loan to buy new sewing machines so that she can support her family and enroll her children in a better school. She is happy about this loan.

loans.use: To buy new sewing machines

loans.name: Kunduz

texts.en:
Kunduz L. is 47 years old snd has secondary education. After graduation from school, she got married and has 5 children. She became a housewife and looked after her 5 children. After her children grew up, Kunduz decided to find a job. She was quite skilled at vegetable canning. This kind of product is in big demand in the local market.

In the market “Safariyon” in Dushanbe, Kunduz rented a stall where she could sell her canned vegetables. She sells her products both wholesale and retail and has been doing this type of business for 11 years.

With this loan of $1200, Kunduz is going to buy tomatoes, cabbages, and cucumbers for canning. This will allow her to increase the range of products she sells during the winter period when fresh vegetables are in short supply. In comparison with her competitors, Kunduz’s products have a low price, which gives city dwellers an opportunity to obtain canned products at reasonable prices. Kunduz plans to pay off the loan over a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, cabbages and cucumbers for canning

loans.name: Sayfiddin

texts.en:
Sayfiddin V. is 34 years old and lives in Vakhdat district, Tajikistan. He has secondary education, is married, and has got 3 children. He is a taxi driver.

Sayfiddin has also been doing stockbreeding for 10 years. This activity is an additional source of income for him. With this loan of $1000, he is going to buy 2 bull-calves to fatten. He will use the income which he gets from his taxi service to pay off the loan, so that he will be able to keep the bull-calves for himself. This loan will help him increase the number of cattle he can raise and also give local inhabitants the chance to obtain meat near home at a low price. Sayfiddin is going to pay off the loan over a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves to raise and fatten

loans.name: Kubra

texts.en: Kubra E., her employee is pictured, owns a car wash in the town of Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Kubra is looking for funding so that she can invest in a new power sprayer for her business. This is Kubra’s third loan cycle with Norwegian Microcredit which means that she has proven herself to be a trust worthy customer.

loans.use: To purchase a new power sprayer for her car wash

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en: Eldar M. owns a small tailor shop in the town of Khachmaz which is located on the Norh Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Eldar has already paid back his first loan with Norwegian Microcredit and is now looking for funding so that he can purchase a higher quality sewing machine as well as other miscellaneous items needed for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a higher quality sewing machine as well as other misc. items for his shop.

loans.name: Serdar

texts.en: Serdar Z. owns a small fabric stand in the town of Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Serdar runs his stand out of the local Bazaar and has successfully paid back two loans with Norwegian Microcredit in the past. Serdar is looking for funding in order to increase the quantity and quality of his fabric inventory.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and quality of his fabric inventory.

loans.name: Mirzo

texts.en:
Mirzo M. is 48 years old and is a historian. He is married and has got 3 children. Currently, Mirzo is working on a project as a consultant, but he grew up in a village so he is skilled at cattle raising from childhood. He has 1 bull-calf and some land where he grows corn and clover for cattle. This business is an additional source of income.

With this loan of $875, Mirzo is going buy 3 bull-calves to raise and then sell. This loan will allow him to increase the number of cattle he can raise and also give local inhabitants the opportunity buy meat near home at a low price. Mirzo is going to pay off the loan over a period of 10 months.

loans.use: to buy 3 bull-calves to fatten and sell

loans.name: Gulare

texts.en: Gulare A. owns and operates a small stand in a bazaar located in Khachmaz, Azerbaijan where she currently sells many different types of sandals. Gulare has already successfully paid back a loan from Norwegian Microredit showing herself to be a reliable customer. Gulare is looking for funding once again so that she can increase and diversify the inventory of her small stand.

loans.use: To increase  the quantity and variety of her sandal inventory.

loans.name: Ramiz

texts.en: Ramiz N. owns and operates a clothing stand in Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Ramiz has already successfully repaid one loan with Norwegian Microcredit showing that he is a trustworthy customer. Ramiz would like to obtain funding once again so that he can increase the quantity and quality of his inventory.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and quality of his inventory

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
Abdul Q. is 40 years old and an inhabitant of Yavan district, Tajikistan. He has higher education, is married, and has got 5 children. Currently Abdul works as an engineer in the State Enterprise for Auto Road expansion, but he has also been doing stockbreeding for 20 years. This kind of activity is an additional source of income.

With the loan of $575, Abdul is going to buy 2 calves. This loan will help him to increase the number of cattle and will also give local inhabitants the opportunity to buy meat near home at a low price. Abdul is going to pay off the loan over a period of 8 months.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves

loans.name: Terane

texts.en: Terane Z. (pictured on the right next to her sister) owns and operates a small market with the help of her sister and other family members in the town of Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Terane is looking for funding so that she can increase the variety of her inventory. She wants to offer foods that are used in making meals rather than only selling snack items to be had with tea.

loans.use: To purchase food items for her store inventory.

loans.name: Hemid

texts.en: Hemid S., his employee is pictured, owns and operates a small market in the town of Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Emid is looking for funding so that he can fill the shelves of his business with a greater quantity and variety of goods.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for his store.

loans.name: Imran

texts.en: Imran A. owns and operates a small Cell Phone and accessories shop in the town of Khachmaz located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Imran is looking for funding so that he can increase his inventory for the seasonal increase in his business. The Khachmaz region in Azerbaijan is a farming region and the local population receives a good portion of their yearly income in the summer and early fall after selling their fruits and vegetables to the markets in Baku and Russia. It is this time of year that the local population has money and makes a majority of their purchases.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for his cell phone store in time for the summer rush.

loans.name: Oktay

texts.en: Oktay A. owns and operates a small fruit and vegetable stand at his local Bazaar in Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Oktay is looking for funding so that he can increase the quantity and variety of produce he has to offer to his customers.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and variety of fruits and vegetables he can offer.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Huseyin

texts.en: Huseyin R. owns and operates a small stand in a bazzar in the town of Khachmaz which is located on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Huseyin has already successfully repaid a loan from Norwegian Microcredit proving that he is a reliable customer. Huseyin is looking for funding so that he can purchase more summer footwear that his customers are seeking.

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of summer footwear for his stand.

loans.name: Amara

texts.en:
Amara K. is thirty-six years old, married with four children. He is a very innovative man who started a small workshop for repairing bicycles. Many youth have sports bicycles and Amara creatively started his workshop just outside the open market where many customers now take their bicycles for repair.

Amara would like to improve his service by purchasing spare parts so as to have an inventory on hand, and also procure some needed tools. He is requesting a loan of $150 from SMT to help him expand his business activity.

loans.use: Purchase bicycle spare parts to keep on hand to improve service

loans.name: Adama

texts.en: Adama J. is thirty-eight years old, married with five children.  Her husband has no job and Adama provides for the family’s basic needs.  She sells palm oil on a small scale around her home in Makeni Town in Sierra Leone, and she would like to expand her business.  Adama would like to provide her children with at least a basic education but so far she can not do so as her income is insufficient to meet school expenses. She is requesting a loan of $175 to purchase 40 gallons of palm oil to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her inventory of palm oil

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa B. is twenty-seven years old and married with one child. She started her business five years ago but could not expand due to lack of capital. Hawa and her husband have a microbusiness selling kerosene, diesel and petrol mainly to motorbike riders in liters, in Magburaka Town in Sierra Leone. Their business income is too small to meet all their household expenses.

Hawa’s previous loan from SMT helped her diversify their business to include grocery items and she would now like to further expand her business for more profit. Her plan is to save money for her child’s future education and medical care. She is therefore requesting a loan of $175.

loans.use: Increase and diversify her stock of grocery items

loans.name: David

texts.en: David K. is fifty-two years of age and married with three children.  David is one of only a few bakers in Magburaka Town in Sierra Leone who supplies bread to the community. At certain periods, David can not meet the demand for bread due to lack of capital.  His previous loan from SMT helped him purchase bags of wheat flour and he would now like to increase his production even more.  He is therefore requesting a loan of $350 to purchase raw materials for his bakery, including flour and yeast.

loans.use: Purchase stock of flour and yeast for his bakery

loans.name: Aydin

texts.en: Aydin lives in the village of Yenikand in the Salyan region. He is 27 years old and is single. He  has run an auto-repair business since 2003. With this business he has been able to provide for himself and prepare for the  future.  Now he would like a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts. He wants to offer better service to his customers and increase the number of customers.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his auto repair shop

loans.name: Vusal

texts.en:
This single man is 25 years old and  lives in the Yenikand village of the Salyan region.
He has 3 years of experience in this business. He would like  a loan of $600 to buy fertilizer and orchard medicines.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and orchard medicines

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en: Bilal is 25 years old and is single. He lives in Yenikand village of the Salyan region. He has a small plot of land that he has been farming for 4 years.Now he would like a  loan of $1200 to buy orchard medicines and an additional plot of land.

loans.use: To buy orchard medicines and a plot of land

loans.name: Shukur

texts.en:
Shukur is 58 years old and lives lives in the Khaladj village of the Salyan region. He is married and has 5 children. Shukur has been growing vines for 20 years.
Now he applies for a loan of $1200 to buy orchard medicines. He plans to improve vine growing to get a  richer harvest.

loans.use: To buy orchard medicines

loans.name: Cecilia Albina

texts.es:
Mrs. Ceci G. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and her 4 children, aged 13, 8, 5 and 3. The two eldest children are in school and the two youngest will be going to the same school. Her husband is a government eemployee who works on construction projects. He recently changed positions and now works paving roads.

Ceci owns and runs a store where she sells all kinds of products, particularly food products. Thanks to her good client service and the variety of products in her store, she now has a large number of clients in the neighborhood. She says that her most popular products are sugar, charcoal, wine and milk.

Ceci comments that due to her husband's work and low salary, she finds herself working just to meet the family's expenses. The people of the neighborhood consider her a strong and enterprising woman, and she is admired within the community.

She needs the loan to be able to stock more merchandise, especially the items in high demand by her existing neighborhood clientele. As one of few convenience stores in the area, she finds herself enjoying lots of demand during this cold season.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Ceci G. tiene 41 años de edad, vive en pareja y tiene 4 hijos de 13, 8, 5 y 3 años respectivamente. Los dos mayores están estudiando y los menores van a ir también a la misma escuela. Su pareja es un empleado público y trabaja en obras de construcción. Recientemente ha cambiado de trabajo y ahora trabajo con pavimentos.

La Señora es dueña y administra un almacén en donde vende todo tipo de productos esencialmente comestibles,gracias a su buena atención y variedad de productos, hoy día tiene un gran numero de clientes en el barrio. Relata ella que lo que más vende en su local es azúcar, carbón, vino y leche.

Cuenta la señora que debido al horario de trabajo de su marido y al bajo salario que este percibe, ella se encuentra trabajando sola para poder costear los gastos de la familia; por lo que la gente del barrio la considera una mujer fuerte y emprendedora, admirada por varia gente del barrio.

Requiere el crédito para así poder abastecerse con más mercaderías, especialmente las más solicitadas por su clientela ya formada del barrio. Como una de las pocas despensas del área, ella se encuentra con una alta demanda debido a esta época de frío.

loans.use: Buy merchandise: flour, sugar, coffee, milk and eggs

loans.name: Ceveriano

texts.es:
Mr. Ceveriano T. G. is 59 years old and married with 4 children, aged 28, 26, 24 and 8. The youngest child is currently in school while the older children are all working. One of the children is a degreed systems analyst, another is an engineer working in electronics and another works in topography. All of the children help the family with their earnings, in a lovely show of filial reciprocity.

Ceveriano works with his wife in a small stall that they opened in the Municipal Market of their city; they sell all kinds of products including lettuce, tomatoes, onions, carrots, etc. They have been in retail businesses for 20 years; 8 years ago they were able to open their own fixed stall in the market.

They have very good sales, thanks to the location of their sales stall. People come to the market every day to buy necessities while others that work in the area come to eat lunch in the market's restaurants. A few months ago they started selling "family budget baskets", which are baskets of preselected varied items sold for a affordable price.

Every morning their work day begins at 5 AM to be ready to open the sales stall at 6 AM. Ceveriano and his wife work alone, just the two of them, except on Sundays when they have an additional employee to help them sine demand is much higher on Sunday.

They need a loan to be able to stock the stall with more seasonal products, such as onions, potatoes and tomatoes, along with eggs and chickens. The sales of the family basket is a complete success and they continually see more demand for the product.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El Señor Ceveriano T. G. tiene 59 años de edad, está casado, y tiene cuatro hijos de 28, 26, 24 y 8 años respectivamente. El menor está actualmente en la escuela y los mayores están todos trabajando. Uno de ellos es un licenciado analista de sistemas, otro es un ingeniero quién se dedica a la electrónica y el último se dedica a la topografía. Todos los hijos ayudan a la familia con sus ingresos así dando un lindo sentido de reciprocidad filial.

El Señor trabaja con su señora en un pequeño local que abrieron en el Mercado Municipal de la ciudad, en donde vende toda clase de productos tales como lechuga, tomate, cebolla, cebolla de hoja, zanahoria, etc. Están hace 20 años metidos en el negocio de comerciantes y hace tan solo 8 años que lograron poner su puesto fijo de ventas en el mercado.

Tienen muy buenas ventas, gracias a la zona comercial en la que se encuentra, pues la gente acude todos los días al mercado a proveerse de los artículos de primera necesidad, al igual que personas que trabajan por la zona y van a almorzar a los comedores del mercado. Hace unos meses implementaron la venta de “canastas familiares económicas” que consiste en la venta de productos variados pre seleccionados dentro de una canasta a un precio económico. Todas las mañanas empieza su día laboral a las 5 de la mañana para abrir su local a las 6. Trabajan solo los dos, excepto los domingos, cuando emplean a un personal ya que la demanda es siempre mayor ese día de la semana. Requieren del préstamo para así poder abastecerse más con productos de la temporada, tal como la cebolla, papa y tomate así como también huevos y pollos, pues la venta de la canasta familiar es todo un éxito y cada vez tienen más demanda de los mismos.

loans.use: Buy merchandise including onions, potatoes, tomatoes, chicken and eggs in wholesale quantities

loans.name: Crescencia

texts.es:
Mrs. Crescencia Núñez is 37 years old and single with 2 children, aged 19 and 12. The oldest now has his own business while the younger child is still in school.

Crescencia is a professional hairdresser who has been working in the business for 22 years. She started her career as an assistant in a very well known beauty salon in the capital, but once she had saved enough money she opened her own beauty salon in her home. Thanks to her excellent skills, she was able to grow a client following and these days a large number of clients come exclusively to her beauty shop, wanting only Crescencia to do their hair.

Her clientele is made up of people from her neighborhood and folks who have been recommended by her clients. When a client isn't able to come to her salon, Crescencia works in the client's home because she wants to give her clients excellent service. As a result, she does not have a fixed work schedule since although she closes at 7 PM, she remains available after hours or clients who need only call her cell phone to arrange an immediate appointment.

She needs the support of a loan to be able to buy more materials for her beauty salon. Her clients are quite demanding and she wants to keep herself up to date with the latest cuts and styles. To do so she is obliged to update her products and her tools.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Crescencia Núñez tiene 37 años, es soltera y tiene dos hijos de edades 19 y 12. El mayor ya se dedica a su propio negocio como comerciante y el menor aún está en el colegio estudiando.

La Señora es una peluquera profesional y hace 22 años que trabaja como tal. En un comienzo empezó trabajando como ayudante en un muy renombrado salón de belleza de la capital, pero luego de haber ahorrado suficiente dinero optó por abrir su propia peluquería en su casa. Gracias a su excelente habilidad, ella pudo ir formándose de clientela, y hoy día cuenta con un gran número de personas que acuden a su peluquería exclusivamente para que ella los atienda.

Su clientela está compuesta por intermedio de vecinos y recomendaciones de sus previos clientes. Cuando un cliente no puede ir a su local, ella realiza sus trabajos a domicilio, pues ella quiere dar la mayor comodidad posible a sus clientes. Es por esta razón que ella no tiene un horario fijo de trabajo ya que a pesar de cerrar cerca de las 7 de la tarde, ella aún está disponible y a distancia de un simple llamado a su celular.

Requiere del apoyo del crédito para así poder comprar más materiales para su peluquería pues como sus clientes son bastante exigentes, ella desea mantenerse al tanto de las últimas novedades en cortes y peinados; por lo que debe actualizar sus productos y utensilios

loans.use: Buy new products including hair color, creams, shampoo, bleaching agents, conditioners y nourishing hair treatments

loans.name: Esteban

texts.es:
Mr. Esteban F. Lezme is 44 years old and lives with his 4 children and their mother. Three of his children are studying in a private school in the neighborhood while the oldest is married with his own family. Esteban works producing bread; two of his children and their mother work with him.

Esteban makes his bread in the bakery in his house and later he sells it to shops or right in his own bakery. His client following, already well developed, is composed primarily of people from his neighborhood. He started his business four years ago thanks to a loan from Fundación Paraguaya.

From the start the loan gave him, he went on growing little by little, buying new products and equipment to make his work easier and to optimize both his sales and his production. He comments that he wakes many mornings at 4 AM so that he can prepare his products, load his vehicle and be ready to distribute his bread while it is still early.

He needs the loan to buy an oven, since his oven is quite old and is not functioning well. A new oven will allow him to increase his bread production.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El Señor Esteban F. Lezme tiene 44 años, vive en pareja y tiene 4 hijos. Tres de sus hijos están estudiando en un colegio privado del barrio y la mayor está casada y ya formo su propia familia. El señor se dedica a la fabricación de panes y trabaja con su familia (él, su señora y dos de sus hijas).

El Señor fabrica sus panes en su local que se encuentra en su propia casa y luego los vende a despensas o en su mismo local. Su clientela, ya formada, está compuesta mayormente por gente del barrio. Hace cuatro años ya emprendió su propio negocio y lo empezó gracias a un préstamo de la Fundación Paraguaya.

De ahí fue creciendo poco a poco, comprando cada vez nuevos productos y maquinarias para facilitar su trabajo y para optimizar tanto su venta como su producción. Comenta que se despierta todas las mañanas a las 4 para así cargar sus productos para el reparto en su vehículo para así poder ir a distribuir desde ya temprano.

Requiere del crédito para comprar un horno, pues el que tiene porque no está funcionando bien ya que es muy viejo por lo que desea adquirir uno nuevo. Necesita así del crédito para comprar un nuevo horno para así aumentar su producción.

loans.use: Buy a new oven

loans.name: Luís Fernando

texts.es:
I have spent more than 3 years dedicating myself to welding. This business has helped me and my wife provide for our family. I am solicitng a loan of $1,200 USD. for the purchase of raw materials since I have a lot of requests from clients and I have not been able to supply because of the lack of raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Escalante, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo más de 3 años dedicándome al oficio de la forja. Este negocio me ha ayudado a sacar a mi familia, en el trabajamos mi esposo y yo. Estoy solicitando un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls. Para comprar materia prima ya que tengo varios pedidos y no le es podido entregar por falta de materia prima.

loans.use: Purchase of raw material

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
María Guadalupe now has more than a year's experience in the grocery business.

"This business that my sons and I tend to is the source of my family's income. We are applying for a loan of $1000 with which we'll purchase merchandise. Thanks to God we have had good sales these last several months, so much so that I see the necessity to offer more merchandise and a wider variety of items without leaving myself without capital. Through the orientation the staff of the Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva gives us as part of their loan program, many families are receiving the support they need to get ahead."

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Sra. Maria Guadalupe tiene ya más de 1 años en el negocio de la venta de abarrotes. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de nuestra familia en el trabajamos dos de mis hijos y yo. Estamos solicitando un préstamo de $1,000.00 Dlls. Para la compra de mercancía. Gracias a dios hemos tenido buenas ventas en estos meses así que me veo en la necesidad de surtiré mas mercancía y variedad de otros productos sin descapitalizarme. Por la orientación que da el personal de Fundación para la Vivienda progresiva a cerca de los préstamos, muchas familias se están beneficiando con este apoyo para salir adelante.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to sell

loans.name: Efrén

texts.es:
Efrén is a native of San Juanito in the Mexican state of Chihuahua. He is married with three children, all still in school. Two years ago, after experiencing difficulty finding work as a result of his disability, Efrén decided to launch his own business selling sweets and snacks. Little by little he has won clients and grown his business. His love for his children and his desire to improve the well-being of this family have motivated him to work and to give his best effort every day.

Now that he has lots of clients, Efrén wants a sales stall where he can sell his merchandise. He is applying for a loan of $200 with which he will buy the wood to build his business site. He commits to repaying the loan in 3 months. Be an important part of the growth of this business. Efrén and his family appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Efrén es originario de la localidad de San Juanito en el estado de Chihuahua, es casado y tiene tres hijos que están estudiando, ante la dificultad de encontrar un empleo debido a su discapacidad Efrén decidió emprender su propio negocio hace dos años con la venta de golosinas y botanas, poco a poco ha ganado más cliente y ha hecho crece su negocio. El amor hacia sus hijos y el buscar un bienestar para su familia es lo que lo motiva día con día a trabajar y esforzarse.

Ahora que tiene muchos clientes Efrén quiere tener un puesto donde pueda vender su mercancía y está solicitando un préstamo de $ 200 dólares que empleará en la compra de madera para poder construir su negocio, el se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en 3 meses. Se parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio Efrén y su familia agradecen mucho tu apoyo.

loans.use: Remodeling his sales stall

loans.name: Mireya

texts.es:
Mireya is married and has one child. Her husband is a bricklayer. Because his salary was insufficient to cover the family's basic necessities, Mireya, always an enterprising woman, decided to open her own business selling groceries. She started 11 years ago with basic necessities and little by little has added more variety in order to improve her service to her clients.

At the moment, Mireya is applying for a loan of $475 with which she plans to remodel her store; she'll enlarge it, present her products better, improve the store's appearance and as a result, continue her business growth. She commits to repaying the loan in 6 months. Be an important part of the growth of this business by deciding to support Mireya and her family. They sincerely appreciate your investment.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Mireya es casada y tiene una hija, su esposo es albañil y el salario que recibe era insuficiente para cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia, por lo que Mireya, siendo una mujer emprendedora, decidió abrir su propio negocio vendiendo abarrotes hace 11 años, inició con productos indispensables y poco a poco fue surtiendo mejor su tienda para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

En estos momentos, Mireya solicita un préstamo de $ 475 dólares con los que planea remodelar su tienda ampliando el local, para acomodar sus productos de una mejor manera, mejorar su apariencia y continuar creciendo, ella se compromete a regresar esta cantidad en 6 meses. Se parte importante de este crecimiento y decídete a apoyar a Mireya y su familia, ellos te lo agradecen sinceramente.

loans.use: Remodel her grocery store

loans.name: Anadilia

texts.en:
Anadilia is a single woman with 3 children. She lives in a small community called "Los Casabe" in the city of Santo Domingo.

She started working in her business 5 years ago; before that it was her mother's. She works in an establishment where she sells chicken, drinks and other foodstuff to the people in her neighborhood. She is also a teacher and works for the "Secretaria de Educacion" part-time.

loans.use: To paint the establishment and buy more chicken

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Mariana J. S. owns a general store in Magdalena, a community in the Dominican Republic with strong cultural ties to Haiti. Mariana, like most of Magdalena's residents, is of Haitian ancestry; her family immigrated several generations ago in hope of a better future. Mariana sells bread, canned fish, candy, and other edibles; she will use this loan to expand the offerings of her store. Mariana is divorced with three children: Milagro Garcia (28), Jenifer (22), and Yerba (7). She hopes that the further success of her business will allow her to someday buy her own house in Magdalena; she currently lives with relatives.

Note: Mariana is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $800 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in the community and helps ensure that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Store stock expansion

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is married and lives in the community of "Los Casabe" with her husband who works at a construction site. She is the mother of 7 children, 3 of girls and 4 boys.

Antonia sells various kinds of meat to her customers. She sells it on the street to houses and other establishments. On Tuesdays and Saturdays she goes out to sell, and on the other days she prepares the food for sale. She has been in this business for over 10 years.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuff

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia F. sells chilled beverages out of a cooler to her neighbors in the Haitian community of Magdalena in the eastern part of the Dominican Republic. Her offerings include purified water in bottles and single-serving bags, soft drinks, and fruit juices. With this loan, Alicia will buy a another cooler to expand the amount of her stock she can keep chilled to sell. Alicia's entrepreneurship supports her three children: Angela (17), Alfredo (13), and Alana Iris (11). Alicia hopes that as her business grows she will be able to buy a refrigerator and maybe even build a permanent store-front near her home.

Note: Alicia is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $800 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in the community and helps ensure that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Equipment for business expansion

loans.name: Isidora

texts.en:
Isidora R., 48, is married and a mother of two daughters aged 17 and 12. The older daughter is married and has a baby girl that is a couple of months old. Her daughter and her husband also live with her. Isidora makes food at her house to sell. Before starting this business 8 months ago, she had a despensa, a small grocery store, down the street from her house.

Isidora works every day in the morning and afternoon starting at 3 am to prepare the food for the day and ending her workday around 4 pm. She serves about 70 customers each day, mostly neighbors and workers from nearby stores. At times, she goes out in the streets to sell. On average, a plate of food would cost less than US$3.

Isidora is asking for a loan of US$100 to increase her business. She buys her merchandise from Asuncion and needs to purchase more pasta and meat.

loans.use: Purchase pasta and meat.

loans.name: Venancio

texts.en:
Venancio Figuerdo, 40, is married and father of a three year old son. He and his wife specialize in weaving sobrecamas, throws, and typical Paraguayan table runners. Sobrecamas are equivalent to bedspreads made with craft thread that is very typical in Carapegua.

Venancio and his wife travel to other cities, such as Asuncion, to sell their merchandise. He started his business over 20 years ago and has been very successful in keeping his business running. Venancio works from home and watches over his son too. He spends his free time fixing his truck.

He is very grateful for being able to obtain a previous loan which gave him more capital to work with. Venancio needs a loan to buy more material, such as craft thread, to complete more sobrecamas and other products.

loans.use: Purchase craft thread.

loans.name: Sixta

texts.en:
Sixta A. F. is 59 years old, single, and does not have any children. She lives with her brother, 56, and a friend. She owns a convenience store that she started more than 20 years ago. She opens her store every day from 6 am until 8 pm. Her store is connected to her house and located in the entrance. Most of her clients are her neighbors. She sells food products and domestic products, such as brooms, toothpaste, and shampoo.

Sixta buys her merchandise from the market in Carapegua. She is seeking a US$100 loan to increase her inventory at her store. She needs to buy more food snacks for her store. With the loan, she will be able to buy more merchandise in greater quantities at lower prices and increase her profit margins.

loans.use: Purchase food snacks.

loans.name: Romania

texts.en:
Romania P. is married and mother of two children, ages 11 and 9. She is a teacher at an elementary school and also sews at home when she is not teaching. She mostly sews on the weekend, mainly on Sundays when she has more free time.

She has one sewing machine at her house that she uses to put together jackets and pullovers. She began sewing at a young age and decided to start her own business about 8 years ago.

Romania is very thankful for the previous loan she received a few years ago. She was able to invest in more material for her small business. She is currently seeking a loan to buy thread and fabric from Asuncion.

loans.use: Purchase thread and fabric.

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta R. is 42 years old, married, and mother of 5 children. Her husband is a construction worker and she weaves rugs and sobrecamas. Many people in Carapegua work as artisans in weaving sobrecamas: a typical Paraguayan bedspread made from crafted thread.

She started doing this about 12 years ago. Besides working long hours from Mondays to Saturdays, she also travels to other cities to sell her products. She works from her house at the same time taking care of her children. She sells about 20 of her products per week.

Roberta is grateful for the loans that she has received and being able to expand her business. She is seeking a loan to buy more craft thread to weave more rugs and sobrecamas.

loans.use: Purchase craft thread to weave rugs.

loans.name: Odilia Silvina

texts.en:
Odilia Silvina V. started her business of weaving about 8 years ago. She is 29 years old, single, and mother of an 11 year old son. She has her own industrial loom and works from her house. Her days are always very busy, but she tries to dedicate from 8 am until 5 pm to weaving. But besides her business, she always has many things to do and also has to take care of her son.

It takes her about two hours to complete a product. Odilia weaves typical Paraguayan products, such as bedspreads made out of poyvi. Poyvi is a type of craft thread typical in the city of Carapegua. Odilia sells on average about two of her products per day and also travels to other cities to sell her merchandise.

Odilia feels very grateful for being able to expand her production from the loans she has taken out previously to invest in her business. She is seeking a loan to purchase poyvi in mass quantity.

loans.use: Purchase poyvi (a type of craft thread typical in this country)

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is 51 years old and is married to Nestor A.. She makes traditional Paraguayan blankets, throws, and bedspreads. She works from her house on a hand-built loom that she has outside of her house.

Besides weaving, she also has a despensa, a small grocery store, at her house. She started her despensa about a year ago. Julia has three children, ages 28, 22, and 20, whom help her out with her store. All of her children finished studying technology but are unemployed right now and are only working on small informal jobs.

For more than 10 years, Julia has been traveling every 15 days with her husband, and at times by herself, on a two hour bus ride to Asuncion to sell her merchandise. She has about 20 clients in Asuncion that she sells to. She does not sell to stores, but rather sells house to house directly to her customers.

She also practices a common method of payment whereby a client requests and receives the order, and they pay Julia in small amounts every 15 days when she returns to Asuncion until they finish paying off the money they owe her.

Julia and Nestor have been working with Fundacion Paraguaya for many years now. They are an excellent client and very thankful for being able to take loans out from the Foundation. They are currently seeking a loan to purchase craft thread to complete more orders and to expand their business.

loans.use: Purchase craft thread.

loans.name: Juan Angel

texts.en:
Juan M., 36, is married with a daughter, aged 2, and a son, aged 10. He started his copetin, a snack bar, three years ago. He and his wife work at their shop from Monday to Saturday starting at 6 am until 6 pm. His brother also helps him at the store.

Their copetin is located on a busy road in Carapegua. Most of their customers are employees from nearby shops and bus drivers. The copetin sells empanadas, drinks, sandwiches, and food that can be prepared quickly. Before starting their copetin, Juan worked as a shoemaker.

He has been able to expand his business thanks to previous loans and now he is seeking a loan to increase his capital even more, but specifically to purchase more beer and other drinks to keep his business running.

loans.use: Purchase beer and other drinks.

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.en:
Bernardina owns an impressive grocery store next to her home in a small neighborhood in Ayacucho, Peru. She sells a wide assortment of beverages, canned goods, and household cleaning products. She has owned and operated this shop for the past five years, building upon her inventory little by little. However, the majority of her business comes in the morning, when she also sells freshly baked “chapla,” which are small, round, hollow breads local to Ayacucho. This popular food is eaten at every meal, used for sandwiches or as an appetizer when filled with cheese. She spends all afternoon baking bread for the next morning, often with the help of her 3 children, ages 17, 14, and 8.

Bernardina was born in the nearby village of Huancavelica, and moved to Ayacucho when she became engaged. Her husband works for the city in the finance department. She hopes to receive a $550 loan, which she would use to purchase more “harina” (the flour used to bake bread), and continue to add new products to her store.

loans.use: Purchase more “harina” (the flour used to bake bread), and continue to add new products to her store.

loans.name: Mirna

texts.en:
Mirna C., 70, is single and has a daughter, Teresa Mabel, 34, who is married with 3 children. They work together in their business. They have two different activities with which they work in; they make chipas, a typical corn-bread street snack in Paraguay, and also weave rugs and sobrecamas. Sobrecamas are bedspreads that are woven with a craft thread typical in Carapugua. They also use a loom that they built themselves.

They started their chipa business 2 years ago and their weaving business about 6 years ago. They only spend three days a week in making and selling chipas. They rotate turns each time in making chipas. Each time that they make chipas, they make about 130. They start at 11 in the morning baking the chipas in a large oven outsiD.. Then in the afternoon, around 2 pm, when chipas are in highest demand, they travel around the neighborhood and to the downtown area of Carapegua to sell the chipas. They usually finish around 5 in the afternoon.

Their chipa business is larger than their weaving business because it is much harder to export and travel with their woven merchandise to sell. They sell about 30 of their products each week for US$7 each, mostly selling in Asuncion.

Mirna would like a loan to purchase more chipas ingredients, such as corn starch, eggs, and milk.

loans.use: Purchase corn starch, eggs, and milk.

loans.name: María Luisa

texts.en:
Maria R. is a busy woman! She lives in Ayacucho, Peru with her husband and daughter. She can almost always be found behind the reception desk at the “hospedaje,” or hotel, which the couple has owned for over 7 years. She works seven days a week checking customers in, overseeing improvement projects, and managing the hotel's 2 employees. Luckily, she has the help of her husband, who is a co-administrator for the hotel. Next door, also on the busy Avenida de Tres Mascaras, their daughter owns a shop specializing in gum, sweets, and beverages.

Maria is quite proud of her hotel, which contains 24 rooms. It is an upscale lodging, with hot water and private bathrooms. She says most of her clients are business people from all over Peru, along with visiting foreigners. Maria has many goals for the improvement of her hotel, which she says is an ongoing project. She hopes to receive a loan of $1,100, which she will use to put new tile on all 4 floors of the hotel, as well as the staircases. This endeavor is already underway, with beautiful blue hand-painted ceramic tiles replacing the generic white squares presently covering the floors. She is pleased with the new look so far, but the materials and labor are quite expensive, and this loan would allow her to finish the project.

loans.use: Put new tile on all 4 floors of the hotel, as well as the staircases

loans.name: Ignacio

texts.en:
Ignacio A., 50, and his wife, 48, started their business a year ago selling clothing. They run a store located in the city of Carapegua, and also have an 18-year-old son who helps them with their store. They travel to Asuncion, a two hour bus ride from Carapegua, to purchase clothing from Mercado 4. Mercado 4 is a flea market located in Asuncion that sells very cheaply priced merchandise.

Most of the clothing in the store is for women and some for children. They sell jeans, tank tops, women's tops, and long sleeve shirts. The store is open every day from 6 am until 4 pm except on Sundays. Ignacio and his wife are hard workers and are very grateful for the previous loans they have received. They need a loan to purchase jeans and shirts from Mercado 4 in order to restock their merchandise.

loans.use: Purchase jeans and shirts.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly L. has a beautiful view of the park across the street from the hotel she owns in Ayacucho, Peru. She lives nearby with her 6 children, aged 14- 27, and her husband. She is kept very busy running and managing the 23-room hotel, for which she and her husband are solely responsible. She only hires help during “Santa Semana,” (Easter Week) which is a huge event in Ayacucho and brings visitors from all over Peru. She says this is definitely her busiest time of year, and the hotel is at full capacity for several weeks before, during, and after those dates.

Somehow Nelly, between cleaning the rooms, bookkeeping, and checking her guests in, has found time to open a small gift shop in the storefront adjacent to her hotel. She hopes to receive a loan of $600 to expand the inventory of the gift shop, which currently is limited to women’s hair accessories, postcards, and collectible dolls. She also has maintenance issues in several of the rooms, for which she would use part of the loan money to hire a plumber and electrician to fix.

loans.use: Expand the inventory of the gift shop; hire a plumber and electrician

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
From more than a block away, the smell of fresh-baked bread wafts down the streets of Ayacucho, Peru. In the middle of a residential block, behind large metal doors is the bakery that is the reason for the fragrant aroma. Haydee Flora R. answers the door, and gladly speaks about her successful business, which she has run for more than 18 years. She inherited the operation from her parents when they became too old to manage the operation, and Flora has since expanded and improved the bakery.

She has the help of three hardworking employees, and runs a very tight schedule. At 1 o’clock in the morning, the first worker arrives and starts the wood-burning fire that heats the stone oven used to cook the bread. Once the oven is hot enough, he begins the 2 hour process of baking the bread sold in the mornings for breakfast. Next, the workers (who clock 10 hour shifts) bake the other varieties sold throughout the day. The room containing the bread racks and oven is well over 90 degrees, and is saturated with the aroma of fresh baked bread.

Haydee Flora explains she produces over 20 types of bread, such as sweet breads made with sugar as well as French bread, dinner rolls, and many others. Once the bread has cooled, it is packaged in bags and distributed to small shops all over the city. She allows her employees to eat as much bread as they like, and says she herself has never grown bored of the bread she and her family eat daily. She lives in a home adjacent to the bakery with her husband and three children. She hopes to receive $1,000, which she would use to purchase the massive sacks of flour and sugar needed everyday, as well as repair the tricycles used for bread distribution.

loans.use: Purchase the massive sacks of flour and sugar needed everyday, as well as repair the tricycles used for bread distribution

loans.name: Yaneth

texts.en:
Yaneth R. lives in a small community on the outskirts of Ayacucho, Peru, with her husband and 2 children. She owns and operates a sizable grocery store, supplying the neighborhood with soda, canned milk, cleaning products, and a multitude of other items. Her most popular product is baby diapers, which she sells daily, either individually or in large packs. Her clients are friends, family, and neighbors, who often stop in the store just to say hello or have a chat.

She has run this shop for three years. Prior to opening the store, which is just down the street from her home, she worked at a small kiosk in the informal market in the city center. Yaneth, who’s friends call her Yanita, much prefers working at the shop because it is closer to home, so she doesn’t have to commute into town and has more time with her children, who are both in school. The space is also much larger than the kiosk where she worked, allowing her to hold more inventory and continually expand her product line.

She hopes to receive a loan of $300, which she would use to purchase more of the most popular products to have on hand. She would also use part of the money to begin selling more specialized, high-end beauty products, which has been a goal of hers for several months.

loans.use: Purchase more of the most popular products to have on hand; begin selling more specialized, high-end beauty products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and repair her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase tools to open a new business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothes for her inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.en: Shahnoza R. and her husband sell gold jewelry made locally. Their business is located at the central market where they have a trading place. Shahnoza buys goods from local producers and her husband helps at the market. The demand for her goods is high because Tajiks traditionally give gold jewelry for different family events. However, the business is difficult because products are expensive and the profits are not large. A year ago, Shahnoza received a loan from Microinvest that allowed her to purchase more jewelry to sell. Now she is requesting a loan of $1200 to finance new stock.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Faizihon

texts.en: Faizihon D. specializes in selling greens and vegetables. She has a regular trading place at the central market of Isfara town. Her entrepreneurship experience covers several years and has brought welcome income to her family budget. Her husband works, but his income is not regular. Faizihon is 47 years old and she has several children. A year and a half ago, she got a $100 loan from Microinvest and used it to purchase vegetables. Since that time, she has gotten regular loans from Microinvest that have helped in her sales every day. She is now asking for a $200 loan to renew her current capital and purchase more produce.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Shoira

texts.en:
Shoira is teacher by profession and has taught in school. She has a big family and many expenses in this connection. One of her sons studies in university and two others study at school. Because the salary of teacher is not enough, she decided to make a full-time business. Her husband returned from Russia recently, and they have put all their money into the expansion of the business.

At one time, Shoira sold only a limited number of food products but she has now increased the assortment of goods to include toys and industrial goods. She has a small shop near her house where they trade from morning till evening. A year ago, Shoira received her first loan from Microinvest and continues to benefit from it. Now she has a good business and has asked for another loan of $500 for 10 months to help her expand her business. (You see Shoira and her husband in the photo.)

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair their house

loans.name: Ochahon

texts.en: Ochahon J. is married and has three minor children. She specializes in selling rice. Rice is the most important Tajiks food product, because it is used to prepare Tajiks plov (pilaf). To buy goods, Ochahon goes to a wholesale market that is held once a week in neighboring Kyrgyzstan. Ochahon then sells rice all the week in the central market. Her husband doesn't work and brings no income to the family, so all family expenses are on her shoulders. A year and a half ago she got her first loan from Microinvest. This helped her to expand her business and she continued to get new loans. She plans to use the money from this new loan for the purchase of rice.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Nazirjon

texts.en:
Nazirjon H. is married and has two small children. His family lives with his parents who are very old and on pensions. Nazirjon is a hairdresser, but because his income is very small, he also has this business. His wife works at home looking after their children and also selling different food products from a room that Nazirjon made into a shop.

Every day, Nazirjon goes to bazaars in different kishlaks to trade. Afterwards, he comes home, rests, and cuts his neighbors' hair. All of this work forms his family income. He spent his first loan to expand the assortment of perfumery and small goods. As his business has grown and is comparatively big, he needs money for its expansion. He has applied for a loan to increase his business.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Nafesa

texts.en: Nafesa lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan with all the members of her family. She is a flower maker who makes good designs because she is very talented. She works in her home and she wants to take a group loan to rent a shop and buy extra materials to attract more clients and make a good business to support her family.

loans.use: To take a rent shop

loans.name: Matluba

texts.en:
Matluba K. is 40 years old. She is married and has 2 children. Her husband works in Russia for a building company. She is a nurse by education, but because her hospital salary is not enough, she has been in this business 10 years.

Matluba started business with food stuffs and now also sells soaps, powders and other products. She wants to extend the assortment of goods she sells. She buys goods from suppliers on credit and wants to purchase in cash because it is cheaper. Her children help her every day now that they are on vacation from their secondary school. Matluba wants to enable her husband to return home.

loans.use: Expand the assortment of goods offered

loans.name: Biotun

texts.ru:
K. Biotun, продает детские и подростковые одежды. Она в этом бизнесе 7 лет. Раньше работала на платочной фабрике раскройщицей. После сокращения этой фабрики она решила торговать на базаре. Бизнес она начинала с 50 долларов США. Товары привозит сама из Истаравшана. Муж у неё работает токарем. У неё два сына, оба учатся в школе. Биотун хочет расширить ассортимент своих товаров и получить максимальный доход. В следующем году её старший сын заканчивает школу, она хочет чтобы он поступил в университет.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Biotun K. sells clothing for children and teenagers. She has been in business for 7 years. In the past, she worked as a cutter on a factory making scarves. After being laid off, she decided to sell on a market. Biotun K. started her business with $50. She personally delivers her goods from Istaravshana. Her husband works as a turner. Biotun K. has two sons—both in school. Biotun K. wants to expand the assortment of the goods sold and increase her profits. Next year, her oldest son graduates from high school, and Biotun K. wants him to go to college.

loans.use: To purchase a new model of children’s clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Ms. Em H. is 46 years old and lives in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Her full-time job is to care for her five children. Her husband is a hard-working farmer and earns about two dollars a day.

Ms. Em H. would like to purchase a motorcycle in order to carry the family's farm products to the market. She hopes to receive $800 in loans to be able to start this effort.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Kuy

texts.en:
Ms. Kuy P. is 21 years old and lives in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She runs her own grocery store, called Kuy P.. With her current inventory, she only earns four dollars a day.

But she hopes that she can increase this income. She wants to expand the variety of her products. Her current inventory is limited so she believes with an additional $400 in loans, she can add more types of food products.

loans.use: To purchase products for her inventory

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Kuy Phea start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Bou

texts.en:
Ms. Bou L. is 29 years old and lives in her home city of Phnom Penh in Cambodia. She sells fruit in front of a garment factory. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. Together, they earn 15 dollars a day. They also have four children. Both she and her husband work hard and full-time in order to support their family.

Her husband needs a new motorcycle to continue his business. His current motorcycle is not in a good condition to help him continue his driving business. Her husband can be seen in the picture. She hopes to receive $800 in order to make the investment in a new motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to operate a new business

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a knitter with 2 years experience. She wants to expand her business so she wants to take a group loan to rent a shop and complete the purchase of all her materials to attract more clients.  She wants to make a good income to support her family to support them and make a better future for them. She is happy with this opportunity.

loans.use: To rent a shop

loans.name: Zohre

texts.en: Zohre E. owns a household items store in the small town of Devechi located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Zohre is married with one child and is looking for funding so that she can expand her inventory to cover a wider range of household goods. Zohre has already successfully paid back two loans with Norwegian Microcredit, proving that she is a reliable client.

loans.use: To expand her current inventory

loans.name: Aynar

texts.en: Aynar S. owns and operates a small jewelry store in the town of Devechi, located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Aynar has been working in this business for 6 years and is looking for funding so that he can make some improvements to his small shop.

loans.use: To make improvements to his store

loans.name: Lale

texts.en: Lale S. and her husband (pictured here) own and operate a household items store in the town of Devechi, located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Lale and her husband have three children and have been running this business for the last 10 years. This couple has successfully paid back two other loans with Norwegian Microcredit, the last loan being for $800, thus proving they are reliable clients. They are looking for funding so that they can further invest in their store to include better, higher quality items in their inventory.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and quality of their inventory

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Mr. Chun C. is 40 years old and calls Phnom Penh, Cambodia his home. He is a motor-taxi driver and his wife takes care of their three children.

Mr. Chun C. would like to purchase a motorcycle to continue his business. Currently, his motorcycle is wearing down and may not last much longer to allow him to continue to work as a motor-taxi driver. With a loan of $700, he hopes to be able to purchase a new motorcycle.

In the future, they aspire to their own grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Hursheda

texts.ru:
R. Hursheda , молодая энергичная женщина, одна из первых клиентов Микроинвеста. Замужем и имеет трое детей. Муж помогает ей. Раньше работала на платочной фабрике, после сокращения она решила с мужем заниматься бизнесом. R. Hursheda продает детские и мужские одежды. Товары привозит сама из Истаравшана. Hursheda когда едет за товарами муж вместо нее торгует. Hursheda хочет расширить ассортимент своих товаров. Бизнес она начинала с 70 долларов. Сейчас она запрашивает 1000 долларов для расширения сезонных товаров. Хочет поехать за товарами в Китай.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Hursheda R., young and energetic woman, is one of the first clients of MLF MicroInvest. She is married, and has 3 children. Her husband helps her. In the past, Hursheda R. worked on a factory making scarves. After being laid off, she and her husband decided to start a business. Today, Hursheda R. sells clothing for men and children. She personally delivers her goods from Istaravshana. While Hursheda is away, her husband runs the business. Hursheda wants to expand the variety of the goods sold. She began her business with $70. Now, she asks for $1,000 loan to expand the selection of seasonal items. She plans to acquire the goods in China.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality clothes

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann S. is 40 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She has four children. One of her children is employed at a garment factory, another one is a student, and the rest are still too young to attend school.

To supplement her family’s income, Ms. Vann S. and her husband (pictured here) run a small cart selling Khmer noodle to the people in front of a garment factory. This earns them on average around $3/day in revenue.

Recently, this couple needs a motorcycle so that they can pull their food cart in order to make their business more efficient and effective. Thus, they are asking for $1,000 in order to make this investment. They are much thankful for your trust and support!

loans.use: Needs a motorcycle to help in her food business.

loans.name: Mehbare

texts.en: Mehbare N. owns and operates a small clothing stand in the Devechi Bazaar, in a town located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Mehbare has already successfully paid back two loans with Norwegian Microcredit. Her last loan was for $400. Mehare is looking for funding so that she can further invest in her business by increasing her inventory with better quality clothing.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and variety of her inventory

loans.name: Rovshan

texts.en: Rovshan is an IDP from occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He started his business in 2000, and borrowed Normicro loan with $450 amount from Baku branch. After some years he collected a sufficient number of customers and he feels a great need in modern equipment ( big mirror, fan, chair etc), and he is willing to borrow 1200$ to put his plans in reality.

loans.use: To buy new equipment

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Ms. Svay M. is 62 years old and calls Phnom Penh, Cambodia her home. To earn a living, she sells traditional Khmer cakes. Her husband is a farmer. However, they only earn five dollars a day. Together, they have one child.

They would like $600 in loans to repair their house and purchase additional seed. In the future, they would also like to start a business selling clothes.

loans.use: To repair their house and purchase seed.

loans.name: Ayten

texts.en: Ayten D. owns and operates a clothing stand in the bazaar of her hometown of Devechi, which is located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Ayten has already successfully repaid two loans with Norwegian Microcredit. She is looking for more funding so that she can further increase the quantity and quality of her inventory.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and quality of her inventory

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena is a seasoned entrepreneur from Kherson, Ukraine. Married and the mother of one grown daughter, she started her business about 10 years ago at a time when she needed to find a job right away and business ownership was her best opportunity. She currently sells a range of sports apparel at the large Central Market in Kherson. Elena has a reputation for treating customers with care and kind-heartedness, qualities that set her apart from many other businesses which often lack good customer service. Elena has also proven to be a great client with Nadiya Ukraine, having successfully repaid 11 loans. She has requested a loan of $1,000 so that she can purchase new inventory and continue developing her business.

loans.use: Increase inventory of clothing.

loans.name: Ibrohim

texts.ru:
Баходуров Иброхим является клиентом вот уже четыре года. Женат, имеет троих детей. Образование среднее. Жена домохозяйка. Дети работают, младший сын помогает отцу в его деятельности . Он занимается реализацией продуктов питания и хозяйственных товаров. Когда стал клиентом «Микроинвест» его активы составляли 200$, тогда он продавал только хозяйственные товары. После неоднократного кредитования и целевого использования его активы возросли до 2000$ и он добавил в ассортимент товара продукты питания. В дальнейшем хочет открыть еще одну торговую точку. P.S: На фотографии его сын

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Ibrohim B. has been a MLF MicroInvest client for more than 4 years. He is married, and has 3 children. Ibrohim B. has high-school education. His wife takes care of the house. All children are employed, with the younger son helping his father in business. Ibrohim B. sells food and household products. When he became a MLF MicroInvest client, he had $200 in assets and was selling household products. After receiving multiple loans, Ibrohim B. increased his business assets to $2000 and added food products to the assortment of the goods sold. In the future he plans to open a new retail spot. P.S. His son is on the photo.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Imaret

texts.en: Imaret A. (her husband is pictured) owns and operates a clothing stand in the town of Devechi which is located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Imaret is married with three children and has already successfully repaid two loans with Norwegian Microcredit showing that she is a trustworthy client. Imaret is looking for further funding so that she can increase the quantity and quality of her inventory.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and quality of her inventory

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Ms. Morn M. is a single woman of 38 years. She lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She has one brother and one sister. Aside from her full-time job, she also has to take care of her parents.

She works in a garment factory and would like to buy a motorcycle to start a new business. In the future, she also hopes to open a grocery store. She hopes to receive $1,200 in financial aid to take up these endeavors.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Habil

texts.en: Habil is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the occupied Lachin district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married and has two children. He started his business in 2000, and borrowed $500 from Normicro's Baku branch. Habil runs a computer saloon. Sometimes the room remains completely overcrowded. Such a situation leads to losing customers; that's why there's a demand for additional PCs. For this purpose Habil plans to take a $450 loan from Normicro's Baku branch. That is enough to buy a recycled personal computer.

loans.use: To buy a computer

loans.name: Nuri

texts.ru:
Махмудова Нури занимается реализацией домашнего обихода. Замужем, имеет 4х детей, образование среднее. Муж работает сторожем, дети работают и каждый имеет свою отдельную семью. Клиентом «Микроинвест» является более два года, ее активы составляли на 150$. После кредитования добавила в свой ассортимент ремни для мужчин, пластиковые пакеты. Увеличила свой товарооборот на 350$. В дальнейшем планирует увеличить ассортимент и улучшить место своей деятельности.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Nuri M. sells household goods. She has high-school education, is married, and has 4 children. Her husband works as a security guard. Nuri M.’s children are all employed and have their own families. Nuri M. has been a client of MLF MicroInvest for more than 2 years. She had $150 in loans from MicroInvest, which she used to add belts and plastic packages to the assortment of the goods sold and increase her sales volume by $350. In the future, Nuri M. plans to expand her product selection and improve the place of business.

loans.use: For business expansion and improvements

loans.name: Yagut

texts.en: Yagut R., with the help of her family, owns and operates a small clothing stand in the town of Devechi, which is located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Yagut has re-paid two other loans from Norwegian Microcredit in the past, which shows that she has a low risk of default. Yagut is looking for further credit so that she can expand her inventory.

loans.use: To expand her current inventory

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mr. Chea D. is 48 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He works in the recycling industry while his wife sells fruit. Together, they earn a combined income of 11 dollars a day. They also have four children.

Mr. Chea D. would like to purchase a motorcycle to run his recycling business. He also wants to increase the range of fruit for his wife's stand. He hopes that $1,000 in loans can help achieve these goals.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Mahiye

texts.en: Mahiye S. sells women’s and children’s clothing out of a stand in the town of Devechi, which is located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Mahiye is looking for funding so that she can increase the variety of her inventory and increase her customer base.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and variety of her inventory

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en: Lubov runs a business selling children’s clothing at a large market in Kherson, Ukraine. She started selling about 10 years ago. In that time she has expanded her business to include five different sales locations in the market, giving her great exposure to potential customers and a good position for further growth. Lubov’s business is following a trend in the small market economy in Ukraine, where consolidation is taking place and successful vendors are able to grow and replace other small business that were not sustainable. Lubov has benefited from the financial services provided by Nadiya Ukraine, using capital from 18 loans to expand and develop her business. She has requested an additional loan of $1,000 to help her purchase new inventory and increase her product assortment.

loans.use: Increase inventory of children's clothing.

loans.name: Ababil

texts.en: Ababil is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She is 48. She started her business in 1998. Ababil's business depends on the seasons and she has to buy fruits and vegetables from season to season. Her first $500 loan she received from Normicro Baku branch. For summer purchases she is wishing to borrow $600 from the same organization.

loans.use: To increase variety of seasonal goods

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en: Ludmila P. is a hard-working entrepreneur from Pavlograd, Ukraine. After losing her husband in an accident, Ludmila decided to leave her previous job and start her own business. She has been self-employed for five years now. Her business provides the only income for Ludmila and her 15-year-old daughter. Despite difficult circumstances, Ludmila has done well with her business. A convenient location for her store and her energetic attitude and respect for her customers have been keys to her success. Ludmila would like to continue developing her business and has requested a loan for $1,000 to help her purchase new shoes so that she can expand her product selection.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for shoe sales.

loans.name: Inoyat

texts.ru:
Inoyat Y. is 39 years old, has a secondary-school education and is married with two children. For the last four years, while her husband is at work and her children are in school, she has sold men’s and children’s clothing.

She started her business by selling children’s clothing, but thanks to careful borrowing from MFI MicroInvest, was able to increase sales, add men’s clothing to her selection and double the value of her business. She has come to us for a loan of $125 to increase her product selection, and to open up a permanent location for her shop.

Translated from Russian by Sabina H., Kiva Volunteer.

Ёкубова Иноят 39лет, образование среднее. Замужем имеет двоих детей. Муж работает, дети учатся в школе. Вот уже 4года занимается продажей мужской и детской одежды. Начала свою деятельность с продажи детской одежды. Постепенно после кредитования в «Микроинвест» увеличила товарооборот и добавила в свой ассортимент мужскую одежду. Сейчас её активы увеличились в два раза. В дальнейшем хочет увеличить ассортимент и приобрести постоянную торговую точку.
